Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The intragenomic conflict between the meiotic driver Abnormal Chromosome 10 and its suppressor in Zea mays.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abnormal chromosome 10 (Ab10) is a chromosome found in maize that breaks the rules of Mendelian genetics. The general assumption of genetics is that every trait, gene, and chromosome has a 50% chance of being passed on to the next generation. In most varieties of maize, Ab10 cheats these odds and shows up in 70-80% of offspring. However, other varieties suppress this selfish activity. This research will investigate how the individual maize plant fights back and stops the selfish chromosome from spreading quickly through the population. The use of high-throughput sequencing across a geographically diverse group of maize varieties with the ability to suppress Ab10 will identify the genes that evolved to police selfish elements and restore balance to the genome.

Selfish elements are likely common in nature. An understanding of the race between a cheating chromosome and the genes that evolved to stop it tells the story of natural selection acting at the DNA level. Ab10 cheats during meiosis, a crucial process by which an organism parcels its DNA into gametes (seeds and pollen) and then passes it on to its offspring. Understanding how the selfish chromosome is halted illuminates the steps of the careful dance of chromosomes through meiosis and into the next generation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was funded to identify the gene or genes associated with a novel form of chromosome movement called neocentromere activity. Specifically, we were trying to find the factors associated with the movement of heterochromatic domains containing the TR-1 repeat by analyzing gene expression in meiocytes from lines that differ with respect to the presence or absence of this form of neocentromere activity.  

Prior data had shown that neocentromere activity on heterochromatic domains containing the major 180 bp knob repeat is activated by a specialized kinesin gene that encodes a microtubule-based motor protein.  Given that 180 bp repeats and TR-1 repeats have a similar manner of neocentromere activity, we speculated that TR-1 repeats would be driven by a similar gene.  To identify the TR-1 gene, we chose to assay three different variants of maize Abnormal chromosome 10 (Ab10) that is responsible for both forms of neocentromere activity:  Ab10-I, which shows both 180 bp and TR-1 activity, Ab10-II, which shows 180 bp activity but no TR-1 activity, and K10L2, which shows TR-1 activity but no 180 bp activity.  Two isolates of Ab10-I and Ab10-II were used, and one isolate of K10L2.  For each of these we had paired wild type samples from the same ears, and all treatments were performed in triplicate.

For each separate plant, the anthers, containing meiocytes, were first dissected to verify that the anthers were undergoing meiosis. Properly staged anthers were frozen, used to isolate RNA, and NGS stranded sequence libraries were created.  The 32 samples were then barcoded and run on Illumina Nextseq using PE75 reads which, given the size of the maize transcriptome, resulted in about 20X coverage per sample. These data are very high quality, well annotated and reliable.

To interpret the data, we first carried out a de novo transcriptome assembly using Trinity using 17 of the 32 samples expressing neocentromres. Trinity then subsequently performed alignment of all 32 samples to the de novo assembly using Bowtie and an abundance estimation of FPKM values.  FPKM values were compiled into one file and split into two groups: those containing TR-1 movement, and those without TR-1 movement. Perl scripts were used to identify contigs that were expressed in lines with TR-1 activity but were not expressed in lines without TR-1 activity.  This simple yes/no analysis did not reveal any obvious candidates for the TR-1-specific motor.

Since aberrational read mapping or areas of homology could result in small FPKM values and artificially exclude gene candidates, a differential expression analysis was also performed looking for genes with the widest fold change in expression between lines with and without TR-1 activity. The analysis was again run on Trinity and results were ordered by their false discovery rate. A custom script employed BLASTX to annotate all differentially expressed transcripts and 134 contigs annotated as kinesins were then closely examined.  By these assays, we found no kinesins that are differentially expressed, even at a low level, in a way that correlates with TR-1 neocentromere activation.  A much more nuanced and thorough analysis is required before we can conclude that no genes are correlated with TR-1 activity.

To further our community ties, we participated for six months in the Clarke County Mentor Program that pairs adults in the community with underprivileged high school students in the area.  We also trained a highly successful undergraduate student Amy Webster who received a Goldwater Scholarship and two major awards from the Genetics Department (top student and best thesis).
